I searched and searched further and further until the forest ended and I landed in Siedlƒôcin already after 22:00. I had planned to use a football field, but passing by I saw a playground. I know this is very unethical, but I'll disappear from here at 3:00 anyway, so I shouldn't bother anyone.

So I set up between the ladders and the slide, where there's almost sufficient space for the length of my body.

I have comfort here ensured by the fact that I'm separated by barriers. Thanks to this, no one should see me.

There's nothing left for me but to finally enter my sleeping bag and go to sleep.

13.title: Birthday
13.content:
The night on the playground was quite pleasant. The temperature at this place was good, and despite the lighting that was on all the time, it didn't bother me too much. I was curled up in my sleeping bag so much that I only saw darkness anyway. Although thanks to this, I had easier packing in the morning. I also noticed that the barriers are all covered in dew, I made a mistake here, because I didn't put everything in the backpack for the night, but nothing major happened.

In the morning, when I got up at 3:00, there were no kids on the playground yet, so I quickly packed up before they arrive and set off on the route.

Today, two main peaks on the list to check off await me, but more on that later. Now I'm heading towards Okole and start traversing villages to get closer to this mountain.

What an absurdity. At one point, being in the area of Chro≈õcicka Pass, suddenly the trail seemed to have ended. This is a paradox, because the signs on the trees clearly indicated that it leads this way. It looks like I got lost while being on it the whole time. This section was impassable, completely blocked with trees and tall thickets. I started forcing my way through this terrain. Step by step, log by log, I managed to get out of this forest. I lost a lot of time, and my calves are all scarred from thorny bushes, burned by nettles reaching up to my armpits, not to mention my shoes, because my socks are completely soaked. It was going so peacefully and sleepily until now, and here suddenly I have a wake-up call.

Nearby, a river was flowing. So I decided to take advantage of this and step into the water with my feet. I washed them of all the dirt that was on them, and also immediately washed those already wet socks, changing to fresh ones. Immediately my morale lifted a bit.

Not for long, because a moment later I came across a section of trail that was fenced off by a local farmer. As if it simply disappeared. I had to force my way through the grass again to get to the summit.

Generally, this section is terribly neglected. Signs on trees are faded, or there aren't any at all. As if someone abandoned this place.

I reached the very mountain before 9:00. I decided to take a break here, and at the same time eat the first half of my halva cake without candles, i.e., ordinary halva cut in half. It so happens that today is my birthday. I couldn't have dreamed of a better present than such an expedition.

When I got up in the morning, the sky was divided almost equally by a line into a part covered with a layer of clouds and a cloudless part. The second one no longer exists now, additionally it's lightly windy and quite cool. Such weather doesn't bother me - perfect for conquering forest peaks.

Around 11:00, the sun came out from behind the clouds and it started clearing up. Instantly here in the Kaczawskie Mountains, this has an impact on the entire perception of these regions. Suddenly everything that's here opened up, spaces appeared, light added a lot of color to the hues that reign here. From a boring and dead place, finally something here stirred to such an extent that you want to explore.

At 13:00, I reach Skopiec. Before that, however, I need to replenish water shortages in the village below. Today I probably won't see a store, and even if I do, it will probably be closed - after all, it's Corpus Christi and everyone has the right to rest. I have to rely on local residents.

The gentleman willingly filled my bottle to the very top and told me a bit about this place. Specifically, it's about the fact that the trail currently passes right through his field, and people litter a lot. I agreed with him, referring to what I see in some shelters after weekends.

On the mountain, I took a short break. A mass of people passes through here, the parking lot is about ten minutes at the foot of the mountain. People conquer this peak like an assembly line.

I sat down and ate sandwiches, additionally I need to regenerate my feet, because despite the sun coming out, my shoes are still wet and I quickly want them to dry.

I also ate the second half of my halva cake - this time pretending to blow out candles, and continued on.

Now, to achieve my next goal, I need to get to the Rudawy Janowickie area. When I get there, I'll want to conquer their highest peak, which is Skalnik. First, however, I need to pass a dozen or so kilometer section to Janowice Wielkie, where I'm counting on an open store.

Along the way, when I pass a river, I can't resist and take a quick break to soak my feet and wash my socks. And in this way, after the morning excesses, there's no trace left. Everything clean and dry.

I reach the city at 17:00, but unfortunately the store is dark. I need to at least get water, so I go into a restaurant across the street and without a problem the owner fills my bottle from behind the bar.

I couldn't be more ready than this, so I head towards the mountains. A quarter past 17:00, I enter the Rudawski Landscape Park.

I lost all elevation entering Janowice Wielkie, and now climbing Skalnik, I have to make it all up again, and then some.

A moment after 20:00, I reach the summit. I'm in the middle of the forest, so there's not much to do here. I just collect a stamp and fly a bit further to Ostra Ma≈Ça, where there's a rocky viewing terrace.

It was definitely worth detouring to this point. It's located exactly on the side of the sunset, when it was already low above the horizon. The clarity of the sky added uniqueness at this moment. Magical views of the area with the assistance of fading rays.

Time to descend and leave the Rudawy Janowickie. I'm heading towards Kamienna G√≥ra, where I plan to spend the night.

Already after dark, I sneak through suburban fields. It's dark when I reach a small grove. With a flashlight, I try to locate any place where I can lay out my sleeping bag.

Finally, I found one right by the road, but I need to organize some cut branches a bit to fit. After a moment, I'm already lying in my sleeping bag, exhausted, but ready for another day.

14.title: Guest
14.content:
Yesterday I finished walking very late. It was already well past 22:00 and it got dark. I lay down and I don't even remember when I fell asleep while writing reports. I woke up at 2:00, noticing the phone lying on the ground. This meant I had to finish writing. Fortunately, it was still before the alarm.

And when it rang, I couldn't pull myself together to get out of the sleeping bag. I felt it was chilly, and moreover, I didn't feel like getting up.

Finally, I made the only right decision and started packing. I ate the rest of the provisions. Currently, besides a liter of water, I have nothing. After a few moments, I was ready to set off, leaving my poor campsite.

Today promises to be another beautiful day, the sky is cloudless, you can still see a crescent moon. The chill that reigns in the field again causes me discomfort while walking. I'm heading towards Kamienna G√≥ra, where unfortunately everything will still be closed. Only when visiting the next town will I be able to stop by a store.

After twelve kilometers of walking between fields and forests, I reach the town of Czarny B√≥r. This is a strategic place for me, because, as I mentioned earlier, there's a store here. Finally, I can make up for yesterday's evening hunger. I eat my fill here, also ensuring products for the rest of the day.

Full of energy, I head towards the first goal on the map today, which is Che≈Çmiec.

The Wa≈Çbrzyskie and Kamienne Mountains are a quite specific and demanding region on the Polish map of the Sudetes. Here it's teeming with conical mountain formations, which significantly affect the number of elevation gains. Leading a trail well here, you can really give yourself a hard time.

The idea of this trail is not just rigidly checking off the highest peaks, but also, as far as possible, getting to know these new ones. And this is exactly the case here, where additional, and at the same time exhausting, peaks are added to conquer.

Actually, before I conquer Che≈Çmiec, I had to climb Boreczna, and then Mniszek. The second one is unfortunate in that it's really a steep wall up and in a moment a steep wall down - end of fun. On top, there's also a lot of grass up to your waist, which makes it a tick breeding ground. I pulled at least thirty off myself, fortunately none attached. This is all thanks to the fact that I regularly check myself.

Precisely because this section is so characterized by elevation gains, and this is already the very end of the journey, I was terribly afraid of this day. I hope I'll manage today, and there won't be ruins left of me.

I climbed Che≈Çmiec a dozen or so minutes after 10:00. I spent about half an hour here, because I had a few things to take care of. I had to collect a stamp, and then go up the observation tower. I've been to Che≈Çmiec several times, but I've never been on this tower. It was always either closed, or there were no viewing conditions.

This time they were fantastic, which was confirmed only at the top. A wonderful view of the area, and even those further mountain ranges, immediately put a smile on my face.

I still had to rest for a moment on the summit. There were a lot of people, so I didn't experience mental peace, only physical.

Finally, I started descending from the mountain with a very steep and unpleasant descent, where I had to watch every step so as not to fall. Finally, I managed this feat, although it wasn't easy.

Next, the route passed through Wa≈Çbrzych. Here it's impossible to resist the multitude of stores. So I decided to stop for a short break and load up on a bit more calories.

When I had eaten everything, I started ascending the Wa≈Çbrzyskie Mountains, rising above the city.

When I took a break to take off my sweatshirt, suddenly someone caught up with me and tapped me on the shoulder. It turned out to be my acquaintance Marcin, who lives in the area and decided to take advantage of the fact that you can see my track on the map, so he started tracking me.

I was very happy to see a guest who decided to dedicate his time to walk with me for a while.

I really appreciate such gestures, and despite how symbolic this was, it really lifted my morale and motivation.

Together we climbed the mountains above Wa≈Çbrzych, I pass through Nied≈∫wiadki and finish at Wo≈Çowce. Meanwhile, we talked a lot about his recent mountain expeditions, and I also told him quite a few interesting facts about this project.

Incidentally, he brought me a Snickers and gummies. Such gifts in such moments taste the best. They gave a huge boost for further journey.

Besides this, Marcin carried my liter of water for a while, and also charged my phone to the max with his power bank. Now I don't have to worry about batteries at all.

Unfortunately, all good things come to an end quickly, and as I mentioned earlier, at Wo≈Çowce we unfortunately had to part.

I started descending a very sharp slope covered with stones, where you had to watch every step that could end in a fall. Very slowly, but safely, I managed to descend from this mountain, but now an almost vertical ascent to Borowa awaited me. Like a wall, it rose before me, so I started climbing. After a dozen or so minutes of really hard ascent, I managed to see the observation tower on the summit.

I left my backpack at the bottom and went to admire the views.

These turned out to be, as with all in recent days, reliable. The weather additionally strengthened the contrast to the greenery that reigned all around. At the end, I also cast a glance towards the Kamienne Mountains, which I'm about to head to. I sat for a few more minutes on the mountain and started descending towards the Andrzej√≥wka mountain hut.

Just before 19:00, I reach the mountain hut. I leave the power bank here to charge and my backpack. I'm doing this because a very steep ascent to Walig√≥ra now awaits me. I immediately head towards it. After just under a quarter of a very demanding climb, I'm on the summit. There's not much here besides satisfaction. So I start walking the same route back. However, going this way is much harder for me. Stones slide under the weight of my body. Finally, I reach the end and with relief head to pick up my things.

I also took advantage of the situation to brush my teeth and add a bit of water.

Now I'm fully ready for the further route. However, I'm heading towards yet another mountain, counting on catching the last sunset.

Unfortunately, I only reach there at 21:00, so I was a dozen or so minutes late. However, I can still see the golden aura above the mountain line.

It's already very late, so it's time to descend and head to the place where I'll spend the night, and I still have over ten kilometers there.

As I said at the very beginning, I knew this would be a very demanding day, so I'm prepared to go to sleep very late. However, this is already the very end, and my legs already feel the toil of the entire expedition so much that I had to make some compromises with myself.

A quarter before midnight, I reach Marcowa Pass. There's a large shelter here with adapted bunks for sleeping. The building itself from the outside doesn't impress, but inside it has everything you need.

Next to the cabin, a campfire is still smoldering, I decided to take advantage of this and heat up a roll before sleep. I haven't eaten anything warm in a long time.

Full, I lie down in my bed. This will be my last night on this journey and at the same time the shortest.

15.title: End
15.content:
When I entered the sleeping bag, I don't even remember when I fell asleep, I also don't know if I managed to position myself well, it was so quick.

The alarm that woke me today was set a bit later, at 3:45. This is because I have a slightly shorter distance to cover. Or rather I'd say that you can't walk any more - the trail has to end sometime. Moreover, I have a quite late train home, so I could afford this to make it on time.

I slept so well that I could spend much more time here, but I know what consequences that would have, so I started packing. Packing the sleeping bag went especially reluctantly. A quarter past 4:00, I left Marcowa Pass.

I start the walk with an ascent to the W≈Çodarz summit, from which unfortunately there are no views. A shame, because I was there right during sunrise, which hid somewhere behind the trees. However, the entire orange-red color of the sky was breaking through between them.

Next, I set my direction to the first goal. First, I descend to the town of Walim, to feel the morning freshness of the town there. When I had completely lost elevation, it's time to climb to the summit. I first approach Ma≈Ça, to conquer Wielka Sowa a moment after 7:00.

On the mountain, you can already admire the renovated observation tower, which was out of use for several good years.

So I thought that today maybe I'll be able to use it, unfortunately it was closed and I couldn't get inside.

I sat for a moment to catch my breath. I ate breakfast and was ready to set off towards the last peak on the trail.

It's incredible that today it will simply end like this. So many hours, enormous ascents, a mass of sacrifices just to stand in this place. To now be at the finish and appreciate the toil and path you walked to find yourself here.

Now, to reach the ≈ölƒô≈ºa massif, I need to cover about thirty kilometers. First, I still need to descend from the current elevation, and then walking through villages, finally conquer the last artifact of this project.

Unfortunately, my water is running out, and to the nearest village it's still a ways. I'll have to make do somehow.

I can already see the ≈ölƒô≈ºa massif in the distance with the characteristic transmission tower on the summit. With each step, I'm getting closer to this place.

I'm walking along flat terrain at noon. Around me are only fields and no trees. Heat is pouring from the sky, on which there's not a single cloud. Sometimes a light wind blows, which provides a bit of relief.

In the distance, I see Sudeten foothills that stretch all the way to ≈ölƒô≈ºa peak rising above them, which against their background seems colossal.

Somewhere roughly in the middle of my route today, I reached the village of Mo≈õcienice. It so happened that this is the only store on the route that I'll pass today. I couldn't waste such an opportunity. However, I didn't have to buy anything for supplies. I only took those things that I planned to consume immediately in front of the store. These were standardly cottage cheese, bananas, and some roll, everything I finished off with a handful of nuts at the end. Full and energized, I continued on towards the ultimate goal.

Now, unfortunately, another dozen or so kilometers of fields in full sun await me. This section is unbearable because of this. I feel so tired, as if my head hurts - this is definitely the effects of dehydration. I try to drink as much as I can, but in such conditions even this isn't enough.

A plus is the abundance of cherry trees that occur here. I often pass some abundantly covered with fruit. I pick a few and while marching, snack on them one after another.

Finally, I enter the forest. Finally, a bit of shade, instantly I feel relief, immediately I walk better.

I reach TƒÖpad≈Ça Pass at 17:30. This is my official moment of starting the ascent to ≈ölƒô≈ºa.

I have four hours left until the train and about ten kilometers of route.

I feel that I need a moment of rest, so I stop here for a moment. My legs aren't carrying me as well as I'd like.

Finally, I set off. At the beginning, I pass crowds of people who came to this area.

However, turning after a moment onto an alternative trail, suddenly from the noise it became silence and peace - this is an extraordinary phenomenon.

From this moment, I begin the final ascent. There won't be any more of them on this trail. This is the last one I have on the list.

This final ascent is quite demanding and will stay in memory longer. It leads me over rocks to the Olbrzymki viewpoint. Unfortunately, nothing is visible from this place now, because everything has been overgrown with trees. I need to climb even higher to see anything.

Exactly at 19:00, I finally climb this last peak and thus complete the full list of conquered peaks on this trail.

This is a quite specific observation tower with a ladder that strikes fear into the eyes of more than one tourist. I couldn't resist and went up to admire the views, which still against the background of the sun radiating above the horizon looked majestic. However, I realize that this was the last view on this expedition, and with sadness I start leaving this place.

I have two hours left for the descent. However, the trail sign shows that it should take me an hour and a half. I'm very happy about this, because it means I'll definitely make it. Moreover, the sign with the inscription PKP Sob√≥tka, i.e., the place where the trail ends, awakens no small emotions in me.

I concluded that this trail is the pure definition of me. Every day that I planned, I realized scrupulously. This wasn't chance - pure consequence.

Despite the difficulties of a given stage's fate, I knew what I had to do most importantly to fulfill the goal. There was no way out.

Everything else was a result of variables over which I had no influence. You simply have to come to terms with this. You also have to be able to deal with such variability. And this is precisely what builds true character in a person - certainty that in every, even the worst situation, you're able to find yourself and come out of it unscathed. And there were already several such situations. Thanks to them, I'll certainly become a stronger person.

A quarter before 21:00, I descend to Sob√≥tka.

Here I just need to pass through the city to get to the PKP train station, where my return train will arrive at the same time, and also where there's a dot marking the end of the trail.

I reach it, ending another stage in my life. This was an incredible journey, a wonderful adventure, there will be time for summaries later.
